messages.subject: gendai shoshinmei vs. nakirishimei mei
messages.msgSnippet: Hey guys, I m looking at buying a gendaito that I wanted to use as a piece to leave out to show people/use for photography research, and am currently looking
messages.messageBody:
Hey guys,

I'm looking at buying a gendaito that I wanted to use as a piece to
leave out to show people/use for
photography research, and am
currently looking at buying a piece that appears to have a Nakirishimei
(its a laydown for a
1 million yen rated smith in Slough's book - it doesn't have one of the
two "hot stamps" in his example, but...).

My first question is what do you think of "validity" of this type of mei
versus one that actually got signed by the
smith himself? will these end up just getting attributed to the
appropriate smiths eventually (kinda like the
tadayoshi problem on steroids), or are these treated gimei, or...?
Second, has anybody run into these where
the wrong mei got put on the sword? And finally, this piece wasn't
dated, but has no arsenal stamps - should
I be worried that this is one of those pieces described in Kapp's where
they manage to get a nice hizenish
hada/nie by careful treatment of modern materials?

Any comments would be greatly appreciated.

Thanks,

rkg
(Richard George)
